column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/01/prime-times-for-baker-mayfield/|Prime Times For Baker Mayfield|BY IRA KAUFMAN Not bad for a bridge quarterback. It’s easy to forget the Bucs had no idea what they were getting when signing free agent Baker Mayfield to a one-year deal for $4 million plus incentives in March of 2023. The initial thought for many at One Buc Place was that Mayfield would hold down the position until Tampa Bay could draft its future face of the franchise. Plans change.  That face now wears No. 6 and features a scowl. Mayfield also happens to be one of the NFL’s best quarterbacks in 2024 as we approach Sunday’s regular season finale against New Orleans. It’s not a stretch to suggest Mayfield has been a revelation in Tampa. His career was at a crossroads when he arrived and now he has Todd Bowles and the Bucs on the brink of another NFC South title … and perhaps the NFC’s No. 3 playoff seed. Mayfield’s 39 TD passes rank second in the league and his 71.7 percent completion percentage is tied for second. He’s third in passing yards per game and No. 4 in passer rating. Most importantly
column2: Tampa Bay averages 29.7 points (fourth) and ranks third in total yards. And Liam Coen’s offense is closing with a rush
column3: averaging 33 points since the bye week. Where would the Bucs be without Mayfield? Tampa Bay fans shudder at the thought. And at the age of 29
column4: he’s just approaching his prime. Mayfield has won over Buc Nation with his moxie and competitive drive. When the pocket breaks down
column5: he doesn’t think twice about sacrificing his body on scrambles. And while he’ll never be confused with Lamar Jackson or Josh Allen
column6: Mayfield has run for 310 yards and 21 first downs this season. For context
column7: Patrick Mahomes has rushed for 307 yards and 22 first downs. That bridge quarterback is now directing traffic for the league’s No. 1 third-down offense
column8: converting exactly 100-of-200 opportunities. How about the red zone
column9: you ask? The Bucs rank fourth in the league in cashing in when reaching the opponent’s 20-yard line. After Mayfield’s first season with the Bucs
column10: general manager Jason Licht explained why Tampa Bay had an interest in No. 6 when few others gave him a second look. “Bruce (Arians) has always been a big Baker fan
column11: ” Licht said. “He’s always been in my ear and in Todd’s ear. It’s tough for a quarterback to step into Brady’s shoes — and Baker wasn’t afraid to do it.” The Bucs will head into the 2025 draft knowing they have their franchise quarterback. That’s a comforting feeling
column12: one Saints fans envy. New Orleans went 49-15 in the four years before Drew Brees called it quits. Since 2021
column15: Andy Dalton and Derek Carr taking turns operating under center. “You can see the energy Mayfield brings
column17: a former defensive quality coach for the Bucs. “He has a little of that gunslinger mentality. They’re playing really well together as an offense.” A robust ground game has certainly helped
column18: but Mayfield sets the tone with his feisty approach. Bowles has liked No. 6 since the Browns made Mayfield the top overall pick in the 2018 draft. All it took was one season to win Bowles over completely. “Baker has the keys to the bus
column19: ” Bowles said in the offseason. “He’s driving it.” The Saints need a quarterback — and the Buccaneers do not. That’s a huge edge for Licht as he tries to fill holes on defense in 2025. Bowles craves ball security and there’s been only one game this season
column21: when Mayfield has thrown more interceptions than TD passes. Buc fans forgive Mayfield’s mistakes because they appreciate his bold
column22: aggressive style. When he arrived in Tampa
column23: he wisely said he wouldn’t try to be another Tom Brady. He just wanted to be Baker Mayfield. column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/01/larry-foote-intrigued-with-the-return-of-shaq-barrett/|Larry Foote Intrigued By Shaq Barrett Return|It was Larry Foote’s turn yesterday to play coordinator. The NFL requires teams’ offensive and defensive coordinators to speak to media weekly. The Bucs don’t have a defensive coordinator because head coach Todd Bowles runs the defense. So each week
column2: Bowles has defensive line coach Kacy Rodgers and inside linebackers coach Foote take turns fielding questions. Yesterday
column3: Foote had an interesting answer. He was asked why Bucs sacks king Shaq Barrett pulled an Undertaker
column4: rose up and rejoined the Bucs after spending months in retirement. “When you realize that Monday check isn’t coming in there (laughs)
column7: ” Foote joked. Foote seems to think Shaq is a prideful man and that motivated him to re-sign last week. Coming off an Achilles injury that sidelined him for half the 2022 season
column8: Shaq simply was not himself in 2023. He had 4.5 sacks and just a half-sack in his last seven games. In March
column9: the Bucs made the very uncomfortable decision to move on. Foote is confident Shaq wants to redeem his street cred now
column10: when the Bucs’ have must-win games. “I know he was coming off the Achillies and he just didn’t feel himself
column11: ” Foote said. “Once that body starts coming back
column12: you start itching and wanting to play the game. “You know you’re always going to miss it but when that body starts coming back and you feel good
column13: you’re going to want to get back out there.” Shaq said yesterday in the Bucs locker room his comeback is no stunt. He’s looking to play at least in 2025 and 2026

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/01/liam-coen-explains-why-devin-culp-is-finally-making-an-impact/|Liam Coen Explains Why Devin Culp Is Finally Making An Impact|UPDATED: It took a rare injury to a key player for Bucs reserve tight end rookie Devin Culp to finally get on the field and make an impact. On Sunday
column2: Culp had three catches for 52 yards. Those were his first career catches. One reason Culp only played a few snaps before Sunday was a log jam at tight end. He’s the No. 3 when it comes to being a full-time pass-catching tight end. Ko Kieft is ahead of him on run plays. Culp also hadn’t yet made an impact because the offense he was used to in college was a spread-option
column3: where coaches signal in plays to the team. The NFL and the spread-option don’t mix. That offense is borderline foreign to the NFL
column4: though some NFL teams use some of its traits. The offense used with Culp at Washington last year — you know the kind
column5: where the quarterback claps for a cadence rather than barking plays — is an irritant to Chucky. He often tees off on the clapping offenses on one of his many Barstool Sports platforms. It seems Bucs offensive coordinator Liam Coen is no fan of those college offenses. Coen said yesterday Culp finally is used to how Coen runs an offense
column6: which is far different than what Culp saw at Washington. “Yeah
column7: that’s what I kind of always say
column9: what’s wrong about the no-huddle offense and quarterbacks in high school and Pop Warner are looking at the sideline for a play
column10: ” Coen began. “Don’t speak. Don’t say a word. Get up to the line of scrimmage. Don’t speak. Don’t say a word. Clap for the cadence. Don’t speak. Don’t say a word. “This game is about communication
column11: and how we play this game in terms of [the] huddle
column13: the communication that we have to do is what’s wrong with our [society].” (Joe’s note: Joe believes Coen said “society” but the word he used is sort of inaudible but “society” makes sense given what he said immediately after.) Coen then added that it’s common for people now to text rather than have conversations. And sometimes he finds players mirror that culture and he must work with rookies for them to understand they can’t text in a huddle. “Everybody just texts
column14: ” Coen said. “They don’t speak to each other. That’s what’s wrong. I tell the high school coaches all the time
column15: it’s what’s wrong. Talking to each other
column16: we don’t talk. “And it’s one of those things where [Culp has] had to get in the huddle
column19: and be able to go out and execute that at a high level. That’s not easy to do for anybody that’s never done it. “So glad to see him being able to contribute
column20: and hopefully be able to continue to do some more moving forward.” Joe fully understands why NFL coaches are not fond of the spread-option and the clapping. But this is the first time Joe had heard it explained the way Coen did. So it isn’t just Todd Bowles’ defense that sometimes has to struggle with a lack of communication. Coen does
column21: too. And now Joe wonders if what Coen detailed is part of what Bowles means when he keeps referring to communication. (A Bucs administrator once told Joe years ago that players learning to converse is a real issue because
column23: they just text. This same suit told Joe that sometimes players will play a video game on their phones with teammates in the locker room and rather than talking or hollering back and forth during the game

column54: ""post"": ""Canabuc:  \u201cSo why has Macmillan in the same offense adjusted much faster?\u201d""
column64: because the tight end learning curve for rookies is already a tougher one. Notice that very few TE make an impact their rookie season. TE\u2019s have a lot of different responsibilities on the field.""
column73: ""post"": ""This seems to be a more player-centric issue than a team-wide \u201ccommunication\u201d issue. Coen is correct on the issue of communication in our society in general
column74: and can def see players texting each other from the other side of the room (even guilty of it myself as a 59yo sometimes lol). Culp is being asked to learn an entirely different language when he hasn\u2019t even been asked to learn the alphabet before
column75: so of course he\u2019s going to struggle (could be the reason why he lasted until the 7th considering his physical gifts). It\u2019s really no different than a player coming in with a learning disability that struggles to pick up the playbook
column76: even though his team ran a pro-style offense in college. Some guys are just slower at learning than others
column87: ""post"": ""Play calls are like\u201d sentences\u201d. Each department ( o line
column90: running backs ) listen to a particular part.  The\u201dnoun\u201d maybe for the o line.  The adjective is for the tight ends.   The verbs
column94: etc) Evans doesn\u2019t need to know all the nouns.  He keys on which verb is articulated.  He listens to the \u201cverb\u201d
column95: and the snap count.  Only Baker has to know it all ( which makes qb such a cerebral position). Cody listens for the \u201cnoun\u201d which tells him what to do
column96: and the snap count.  The position dictates the level of difficulty understanding the playbook.""
column105: ""post"": ""Very good and informative article and Let em Bake very astute observations. It explains why Mc Millian didn\u2019t jump out from the get go like everyone thought he would. Joyfully it continues they both continue to get better""
